results.title: Lift to the scaffold = L'Ascenseur pour l'echafaud
results.creator_credit: Jean Thuillier, Nouvelles Éditions de Films and Louis Malle
results.brief_description: This taut, tense and incredibly fast paced thriller features Jeanne Moreau and Maurice Ronet as passionate lovers who embark on a plan to murder her husband. However, the plan goes terribly wrong when the murderer finds himself trapped in a faulty lift. While his lover searches frantically through Paris for him, he grows increasingly more desperate, and she finds herself trapped in another’s scheming plans. Based on a novel by Noel Calef, Louis Malle directs with an audacious vitality, while Moreau and Ronet are wonderful as the callous lovers. The film’s musical score is by jazz legend Miles Davis. The film won the prestigious Prix Delluc, one of French cinema’s most important awards. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Lift-off at the Wackadoo Cafe
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar, Paul Nichola and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lift off”.
How do you get to the Wackadoo Cafe? All you need to do is shout “Wackadoo” and you’re there! These are 10 episodes of Wackadoo Cafe from the children’s TV series Lift off, as seen on ABC TV. Wackadoo is a crazy cafe run under the strict orders of ‘The Boss’. ‘Zelda’ the waitress weaves confidently amongst the customers, while ‘Nearly’ is nervously in charge of the drinks. ‘Cook’ a true artiste, creates works of genius in the kitchen. Regular customers are ‘Wolf’, a faded star, and the three pigs ‘Boris’, ‘Doris’ and ‘Moris’, who invariably display their mean streak. ‘Lonely’ is there too, always waiting for a friend.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Patricia Edgar, Paul Nichola and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: Lifetimes of change: development and growth
results.creator_credit: Australian Academy of Science and Educational Media International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Web of life”.
Shows the changes that take place within the lifetimes of individual organisms. Illustrates the ideas of birth, growth, change and decay by using three examples from the natural world: toadstools, frogs and flowering plants. Also notes the main changes in structure and in behaviour that distinguish a human lifetime. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates the swimming strokes best adapted to life-saving: how to approach a swimmer in difficulties, breaking holds, carries, methods of rescuing by boat and by ring buoy, and the Schafer method of resuscitation.
results.description: This film demonstrates the swimming strokes best adapted to life-saving: how to approach a swimmer in difficulties, breaking holds, carries, methods of rescuing by boat and by ring buoy, and the Schafer method of resuscitation.

results.title: Lifesaving
results.brief_description: This film, which includes a demonstration of land drill by the Southsea Police Lifeguard Corps (England), shows in detail the various methods needed for rescuing a docile person, a turbulent person, somebody really violent, and a tired but clear-headed swimmer. The sidestroke method of rescue, the surface dive necessary if the subject has sunk, and the use of artificial respiration are also demonstrated.

results.title: Lifeline to Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and John Kingsford-Smith
results.brief_description: Adelaide’s water supply is boosted by the 50 miles of piping from Mannum on the Murray. With the lowest rainfall of any Australian capital, heavy industry expanding each year, and a rapid increase in homes and population, the six reservoirs in the Lofty Ranges are unable to supply enough water for Adelaide’s needs. An extra supply of water is pumped through 72 inch concrete pipes to dams near the city.
